The most important inherent limitation on patentable subject matter revolves around the sometimes blurred distinction between an invention and a discovery. Laws of nature or scientific principles that a researcher may 'find' are not patentable. For example, imagine that a scientist discovers that a certain previously unknown form of magnetic wave strikes the earth's atmosphere from deep space, and that this kind of wave has an adverse effect on the transmission of data between the earth and communications satellites. Such a discovery may have enormous commercial implications, perhaps leading to the invention of a device that filters out the harmful effect of the waves. The inventor of the filtering device may be entitled to a patent. The discoverer of the magnetic wave cannot patent his or her discovery. Today, the distinction between discovery and invention is of increasing importance in the fields of genetic engineering and biotechnology.

At its most fundamental, relative brightness identifies the visual contrasts by which we live. Without contrast, the essentials of vision fail to operate; the brain will not identify edges and forms nor perceive depth or distance. The fewer the contrasts, the less able we are to identify details, and the less able we are to navigate the environment. Ideal visual conditions are those where contrasts of relative brightness are most easily identified, where the light source is strong and casts sharply defined shadows. It follows that ideal visual conditions are most likely to generate positive feeling-responses. At the opposite end of the safe/dangerous spectrum, the most hazardous visual conditions are those where the contrasts conferred by a range of relative brightness no longer exist. Complete darkness (as in an underground cave) and complete brightness (as in a blizzard whiteout) are equally fraught with danger. In these extreme conditions of luminance, details are obliterated, and navigation becomes hazardous. Emotion-feelings aroused by conditions such as these are most likely to be negative.

"Farm animals, lab animals, sport horses ... ": our language when we refer to some animals often focuses on their exploitation and on the benefits humans get from them, for example, animals as a source of food, used in biomedical research or for recreational activities. When we refer to some animals as "pets," are we implying their use for any purpose? A pet can be defined, in a neutral manner, as an animal that lives with humans. Another largely used term is "companion animal," which, again, implies that we keep them in our home with the final aim of getting companionship. Some may argue that a fish in the fish tank is not really anyone's companion. However, this term well adapts to domestic species, such as dogs and cats, which we treat kindly, consider as members of the family and our "best friends," and with whom we share our time and financial resources. Differently from other species, companion animals thus appear to represent an emotional — rather than an economical — resource, providing humans with support, comfort and companionship.

Whilst some stakeholders may try to protect the integrity of arts and cultural festivals from their reconfiguration as urban policy tools, we should recognise that policy oriented festivals can still have very positive social and cultural effects. And we cannot ignore the fact that some festivals were established to strategically assist urban areas. In other words, they have always been strategic interventions rather than artistic, social or cultural phenomena. Film festivals are a good example: many of these events were established for economic reasons: for example, the Cannes Film Festival was launched to prolong the tourist season. The Brighton Festival was created for similar reasons. The re-establishment of the Venice Carnival in 1979, following a long hiatus, was also a deliberate attempt to address some of the issues the city was facing at that time, including the lack of provision for young people. These festivities have not been appropriated as urban policy tools: they have always been staged with wider objectives in mind.

Sentiment is very close to emotion in meaning, but when social psychologists use the term sentiment, they emphasize the social aspect of emotion. Early social psychologists used sentiment to refer to the components of human responses that separate them from analogous responses that animals would have. For example, Cooley contrasts love and lust. Although lust is instinctive, we learn what love is through social interaction. In other words, sentiment relies not just on the responses of the individual to the stimulus but also on how other human beings understand that stimulus. In later years, as social psychologists have come to increasingly accepted that social elements are a key piece of emotions, the idea of sentiment has become less distinguishable from that of emotion. In contemporary work, social psychologists often use the term sentiment to distinguish immediate emotional responses from longer-term emotional states such as love, grief, and jealousy. These sentiments can endure for days, weeks, and even years after the initial event that triggered them.

To become a fossil is a long and involved process, and is an unlikely outcome for the vast majority of individuals. The most obvious requirement for an organism to end up as a fossil is that it must become entombed within rock, usually by burial. There are many chances that can prevent this happening. If a mollusc has the misfortune to be killed by a predator, then the soft parts will be eaten. The predator will probably have to break at least one of the shells to gain access to the flesh, so it is unlikely that both shells will survive intact. Even if they do, the two shells may become separated. On the other hand, if the organism dies a natural death, although the soft parts of the body will almost certainly rot away, neither shell is likely to be damaged. The shells are held together at the hinge by fibrous tissues, which are among the last to rot, so there is a reasonable chance that the two shells will remain held together until they become buried.

Sometimes, a monkey grooms another monkey and gets nothing in return. Sometimes an ape courts a mate and gets completely ignored. Cortisol prompts a mammal to try something different, but after a few disappointments it can be hard for the mammal to predict where to invest its energy. This is why we often fall back on the neural superhighways we myelinated in youth. Your electricity flows effortlessly down the pathways built by behaviors that were reliably rewarded in your past. Maybe it was scoring a touchdown, or joining friends to watch your favorite quarterback score. Of course, carrying a ball across a line does not meet real survival needs, but dopamine surges when you expect a social reward. Each brain predicts social rewards from its own life experience. Maybe you lived in a world where social rewards went to someone who cooked a big meal or solved a big equation or found a bar open after hours. There are limitless ways to get social rewards, but the ones we observe and enjoy in youth build expectations that last.

To determine whether a person is lying, we tend to rely heavily on intuition. Unless we catch a lie on factual grounds, the only indicators of a person's dishonesty are tone of voice, body language, and facial expressions — signs that may be too subtle for us to consciously recognize but that can still evoke a strong gut feeling. The problem is that while we can practice our skills at evaluating others' truthfulness in social interactions, without clear feedback on whether our judgments are correct we don't know if we're erring on the side of gullibility or of distrustfulness. This means we're unable to improve over time. Though many people believe they're quite good at distinguishing truths from lies, almost no one in the general population performs with higher than chance accuracy. On average, even police officers, lawyers, judges, psychiatrists, and members of other groups that encounter more frequent and serious lies than ordinary people perform no better.

At its most fundamental, relative brightness identifies the visual contrasts by which we live. Without contrast, the essentials of vision fail to operate; the brain will not identify edges and forms nor perceive depth or distance. The fewer the contrasts, the less able we are to identify details, and the less able we are to navigate the environment. Ideal visual conditions are those where contrasts of relative brightness are most easily identified, where the light source is strong and casts sharply defined shadows. It follows that ideal visual conditions are most likely to generate positive feeling-responses. At the opposite end of the safe/dangerous spectrum, the most hazardous visual conditions are those where the contrasts conferred by a range of relative brightness no longer exist. Complete darkness (as in an underground cave) and complete brightness (as in a blizzard whiteout) are equally fraught with danger. In these extreme conditions of luminance, details are obliterated, and navigation becomes hazardous. Emotion-feelings aroused by conditions such as these are most likely to be negative.

Because of this, white bread may cause a spike in blood sugar, whereas whole grain bread is less processed and has its fiber intact. This allows for a slower release of sugar into the blood, meaning that while white and whole grain bread may have the same total amount of carbohydrates, the way they affect your blood sugar is very different.

Sentiment is very close to emotion in meaning, but when social psychologists use the term sentiment, they emphasize the social aspect of emotion. Early social psychologists used sentiment to refer to the components of human responses that separate them from analogous responses that animals would have. For example, Cooley contrasts love and lust. Although lust is instinctive, we learn what love is through social interaction. In other words, sentiment relies not just on the responses of the individual to the stimulus but also on how other human beings understand that stimulus. In later years, as social psychologists have come to increasingly accepted that social elements are a key piece of emotions, the idea of sentiment has become less distinguishable from that of emotion. In contemporary work, social psychologists often use the term sentiment to distinguish immediate emotional responses from longer-term emotional states such as love, grief, and jealousy. These sentiments can endure for days, weeks, and even years after the initial event that triggered them.

To become a fossil is a long and involved process, and is an unlikely outcome for the vast majority of individuals. The most obvious requirement for an organism to end up as a fossil is that it must become entombed within rock, usually by burial. There are many chances that can prevent this happening. If a mollusc has the misfortune to be killed by a predator, then the soft parts will be eaten. The predator will probably have to break at least one of the shells to gain access to the flesh, so it is unlikely that both shells will survive intact. Even if they do, the two shells may become separated. On the other hand, if the organism dies a natural death, although the soft parts of the body will almost certainly rot away, neither shell is likely to be damaged. The shells are held together at the hinge by fibrous tissues, which are among the last to rot, so there is a reasonable chance that the two shells will remain held together until they become buried.

To determine whether a person is lying, we tend to rely heavily on intuition. Unless we catch a lie on factual grounds, the only indicators of a person's dishonesty are tone of voice, body language, and facial expressions — signs that may be too subtle for us to consciously recognize but that can still evoke a strong gut feeling. The problem is that while we can practice our skills at evaluating others' truthfulness in social interactions, without clear feedback on whether our judgments are correct we don't know if we're erring on the side of gullibility or of distrustfulness. This means we're unable to improve over time. Though many people believe they're quite good at distinguishing truths from lies, almost no one in the general population performs with higher than chance accuracy. On average, even police officers, lawyers, judges, psychiatrists, and members of other groups that encounter more frequent and serious lies than ordinary people perform no better.

Not each and every kind of suffering warranted pity. No one was supposed to feel pity for captured, tortured, and killed enemies. Neither slaves nor Christian martyrs deserved pity in ancient times. Later on, religious communities that preached the gospel of brotherly love and love of neighbor found no difficulty in denying it to those who did not belong and believe. This attitude only started to change during the 18th century. Playwrights reviving the Aristotelian concept of catharsis discovered pity as the most natural and most moral human faculty that should be cultivated by theater, literature, and music. Philosophers who sought a moral foundation for modern civil society praised pity and sympathy as counter-forces of self-love and egoism. Novelists were eager to devise plots and stories that would elicit the readers' pity, inspiring them to become sensitive and sensible citizens. At the same time, hundreds of thousands of European and North American men and women campaigned for the abolition of slavery and the liberation of slaves. Spurred by an "imagined empathy" and using a language of love for those "brothers" and "sisters" whose freedom and human dignity were trampled upon, they engaged in an unprecedented — and ultimately successful — struggle against the slave trade and the institution of slavery.

정답 및 해설
1) 4 [자연 법칙이나 과학적 원리는 특허 대상이 아니며 발견과 발명의 차이가 특허 가능성을 가르는 핵심임을 설명한다. 따라서 "The Thin Line Between Discovery and Invention"가 지문의 내용을 가장 잘 나타내는 제목이다.]
2) 3 [상대적인 밝기 대비가 형태 식별, 거리 인식, 환경 탐색 등 기본적인 시각 기능에 필수이며 밝기 대비가 부족하거나 과도할 경우 감정적으로 부정적인 반응과 위험한 상황이 초래된다는 점을 설명하는 글이다. 따라서 "Why Visual Contrast Is Key to Safe Navigation?" 제목으로 가장 적절하다.]
3) 1 [인간이 동물을 어떻게 분류하고 인식하는지를 글 앞부분에 언급하고 있으며 특히 반려동물은 경제적 자원이 아니라 정서적 자원으로서 친밀감, 위안, 동반자 관계를 제공하는 존재로 여겨진다는 점을 설명하고 있다. 따라서 "The Emotional Value of Companion Animals"가 가장 적절한 제목이다. 4번의 "Understanding Human Relationships with Domestic Animals"은 주제와 관련은 있지만 너무 광범위한 제목이다.]
4) 2 [축제들이 단순한 문화예술 행사가 아닌 도시 정책 수단으로 기획된 경우가 많았다는 점을 설명하는 글이며 Cannes, Brighton, Venice 등 구체적 축제를 예로 들어 애초부터 전략적 목적(관광 유치, 청년 공간 확보 등)을 가진 축제였음을 강조하고 있다. 따라서 "Strategic Roots of Modern-Day Festivals"가 제목으로 가장 적절하다.]
5) 4 [정서(sentiment)와 감정(emotion)의 차이점을 설명하면서 정서(sentiment)가 사회적 맥락에서 형성되고 해석되며 장기적으로 지속되는 감정이라고 하고 있다. 따라서 "Sentiment: A Socially Constructed Emotional State"가 제목으로 가장 적절하다.]
6) 4 [화석이 되는 과정이 복잡하고 드문 일임을 설명하며, 특히 매몰되기까지 다양한 방해 요인들(포식자에 의한 파손, 부패 등)을 언급하고 있다. 따라서 "Fossilization: A Complex and Unlikely Journey"가 제목으로 가장 적절하다.]
7) 5 [유년기에 반복적으로 보상받은 행동 패턴이 뇌에 회로처럼 자리 잡고 이후 사회적 보상을 예측할 때 기준이 된다는 것을 말하는 지문이다. 즉, 과거에 보상이 따랐던 경험은 성인이 되어서도 에너지를 어디에 투자할지 결정짓는 습관으로 작용한다고 지문에서는 언급한다. 따라서 "Why Early Social Rewards Shape Lifelong Behavior"가 가장 적절한 제목이다.]
8) 3 [우리가 직관에 의존해 거짓말을 판별하려 하지만 정확도는 거의 우연 수준에 불과하며 직관을 개선할 피드백도 부족하기 때문에 시간이 지나도 판단 능력이 나아지지 않는다는 한계를 지적한다. 따라서 "Think You Can Spot a Lie? Think Again!"이 제목으로 가장 적절하다.]

9) 2 , is $\rightarrow$ are ["Law of nature or scientific principles"에 수일치를 해야 한다. 따라서 is가 아니라 are가 어법상 적절하다.]
10) 1 , which $\rightarrow$ by which [뒤에 이어지는 절인 "we live"는 목적어나 보어가 필요 없는 완전한 1형식 문장구조이므로 관계대명사 which를 쓸 수 없으며 "Relative brightness identifies the visual contrasts." + "We live by the visual contrasts"로 볼 수 있으므로 by which가 와야 한다.]
11) 2 , whom $\rightarrow$ with whom 또는 문장 끝의 resources $\rightarrow$ resources with [이어지는 절인 "we share our time and financial resources"는 완전한 3형식 문장구조이므로 관계대명사 which를 쓸 수 없으며 "We share our time and financial resources with domestic species."라고 볼 수 있다. 따라서 whom이 아닌 with whom이 되어야 한다. 10번 문항 해설 참고]
12) 3 , have not appropriated $\rightarrow$ have not been appropriated, have always staged $\rightarrow$ have always been staged ["전용되고 기획된 것"이므로 수동의 의미를 갖는다. 따라서 현재완료의 수동태인 "have not been appropriated"와 "have always been staged"가 되어야 한다.]
13) (1) different, efficient $\rightarrow$ differently, efficiently, (3) provide $\rightarrow$ provides [(1) 동사인 metabolized와 used를 수식하므로 각각 부사 differently, efficiently가 되어야 한다. (3) "each of + 복수명사"는 단수취급 한다. 따라서 provides를 써야 한다.]
14) 3 , who $\rightarrow$ whose [바로 앞에 나오는 "brothers and sisters"의 자유와 인간 존엄이 짓밟힌 것이므로 소유격 관계대명사 whose가 되어야 한다.]
15) 3, those $\rightarrow$ that [앞의 "the idea"를 받으므로 단수형 대명사인 that을 써야 한다.]
16) 4 [생명체가 포식자에게 먹힐 경우 포식자가 껍데기를 부수지만 자연사할 경우 몸의 부드러운 부분은 썩어 없어지고 껍데기가 손상될 가능성은 적다고 하는 것이 문맥상 자연스럽다. 따라서 4번의 intact를 damaged로 바꿔서 "neither shell is likely to be damaged"라고 하는 것이 적절하다. 3 번의 damaged는 본문에는 intact라고 되어 있다.]
17) 5 [지문에서는 시각적으로 안전한 조건은 명암 대비가 뚜렷한 환경이며 위험한 조건은 명암 대비가 사라지는 상황임을 설명한다. 또한 완전한 어둠이나 완전한 밝음은 모두 명암을 무효화하여 시각적 탐색과 감정 반응에 부정적인 영향을 미친다고 언급하고 있다. 따라서 빈칸에는 "the contrasts given by a range of relative brightness no longer exist"가 가장 적절하다.]

18) 3 [자연 법칙의 발견은 특허 대상이 아니지만 그 발견을 바탕으로 한 장치나 응용은 특허가 가능하다는 점을 설명하고 있다. 즉, 그 발견은 상업적으로 큰 가능성을 가지고 있을 수 있으며 그 잠재력을 실현한 발명에 대해 특허를 부여할 수 있다는 맥락이다. 따라서 빈칸에는 "significant commercial potential in industry"가 가장 적절하다. 본문에는 "enormous commercial implications"로 되어 있다.]
19) 2 [지문에서는 우리가 동물을 언급할 때 그들을 인간의 목적에 맞춰 사용하는 방식으로 부르는 경향이 있다고 말하고 있으며 "farm animal", "lab animal" 등과 같이 인간의 필요에 따라 쓰임이 정해진 존재로 언어화되어 있다는 것을 예로 들고 있다. 빈칸은 이에 대한 의문을 제기하는 문장으로 "pets라는 단어도 결국은 인간의 필요에 봉사하게끔 정의하고 있는 것은 아닌가?"를 묻고 있다. 따라서 "suggesting their duty to serve human needs"가 빈칸에 가장 적절하다. 본문에는 "implying their use for any purpose"로 되어 있다.]
20) 3 [축제가 단순히 예술적•문화적 목적이 아니라 도시 전략, 특히 관광과 지역 경제 활성화를 위해 만들어졌음을 말하고 있다. Cannes Film Festival이 관광 시즌을 연장하기 위해 만들어졌다는 사례는 바로 그러한 경제적 이유(economic reasons)를 뒷받침한다.]
21) 2 [열량의 총량뿐 아니라 그 열량이 어디에서 나왔는지가 중요하다는 점을 강조하는 지문이며 같은 탄수화물이라도 정제된 흰 빵과 통곡물 빵이 몸에 미치는 영향이 다르다는 예시를 통해 이를 뒷받침하고 있다. 따라서 "It is the source that matters."가 빈칸에 가장 적절하다. 본문에는 "the source is important"로 되어 있다.
22) 1 [지문에서 정서(sentiment)는 단순한 감정이 아니라 사회적 과정을 통해 형성된 감정 상태라고 설명한다. 특히 본능적인 욕망(lust)과 달리 사랑(love)은 사회적 관계 속에서 학습된다는 점을 말하고 있으며 이러한 흐름에서 볼 때 "social interaction"이 빈칸에 가장 적절하다.]
23) 1 [포식자에 의해 죽음을 맞이한 경우에는 조개껍데기가 손상되기 쉽고 설령 남아 있다 하더라도 둘 다 온전히 보존되기 어렵다고 지문에서는 설명한다. 따라서 포식자의 공격을 받은 상황에서는 "both shells will be preserved undamaged"라는 결과가 거의 일어나지 않는다고 하는 것이 빈칸에 가장 적절하다. 본문에는 "both shells will survive intact"라고 되어 있다.]
24) 1 [동물이 반복된 실망을 겪으면 어디에 에너지를 쏟아야 할지 판단하기 어려워진다는 점을 설명하고 있다. 이는 뇌가 과거 보상을 받았던 행동 경로를 무의식적으로 다시 따르게 되는 이유로 이어지며 따라서 빈칸에는 "predict where to invest its energy"가 가장 적절하다.]

25) 4 [우리가 상대방의 정직을 판단할 때 언어적, 비언어적 단서를 명확히 인식하지 못하더라도 직관적으로 느끼는 경우가 많다고 설명하고 있다. 이러한 직관적인 느낌은 뚜렷한 근거나 논리 없이도 발생할 수 있으며 이 맥락에 가장 잘 맞는 표현은 "trigger an intuitive response without logic"이다. 본문에는 "evoke a strong gut feeling"으로 되어 있다.]
26) empathy [지문은 연민(pity)이라는 감정이 어떻게 18세기부터 문학과 철학, 시민사회의 중심 도덕 감각으로 자리 잡았는지를 설명하고 있으며 노예 해방 운동의 핵심 동력 또한 이러한 감정의 확장에서 비롯되었다고 말하고 있다. 이를 가장 잘 나타내는 단어는 empathy(공감)이다.]
27) 1 [자연 법칙이나 과학적 원리 자체는 특허 대상이 될 수 없다는 법적 원칙을 설명하고 있다. 예시에서 자기장을 발견한 과학자는 특허를 받을 수 없지만 그 발견을 바탕으로 장치를 발명한 사람은 특허를 받을 수 있다는 점을 말하고 있으므로 빈칸에 가장 적절한 말은 "cannot patent his or her discovery"이다.]
28) 5 [본문에서는 여러 도시 축제가 단순한 문화 활동이 아니라 도시 재생이나 경제 활성화와 같은 전략적 목적을 염두에 두고 기획된 것임을 강조하고 있다. 따라서 빈칸에는 이러한 넓은 목적(wider objectives)을 반영한 표현이 가장 적절하며 "planned with broader goals in mind"가 이를 가장 잘 반영하고 있다. 본문에는 "wider objectives in mind"로 되어 있다.]
29) 2 [칼로리의 양이 같더라도 음식의 종류에 따라 혈당에 미치는 영향이 다르다는 점을 설명하고 있다. 특히 정제된 탄수화물과 섬유질이 있는 탄수화물의 혈당 반응 차이를 비교하므로 "they affect your blood sugar is very different"라는 표현이 빈칸에 가장 적절하다.]
30) 5 [지문의 핵심은 정서(sentiment)가 사회적 맥락과 타인의 해석에 의존한다는 점이다. 단순한 본능이 아닌 타인이 특정 자극을 어떻게 이해하는지를 통해 감정이 형성된다는 설명이 있으므로 빈칸에 들어갈 적절한 말은 "how other human beings understand that stimulus"이다.]
